title: The Psychology of Listicles

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why listicles are popular, according to researchers?

options.label: A
options.text: They are a new and innovative format.

options.label: B
options.text: They are easy to read and digest, and help to curate information.

options.label: C
options.text: They are a way to present complex information in a simple way.

options.label: D
options.text: They are a way to avoid reading long articles.

multiple-choice.question: What is cognitive fluency, and how does it relate to listicles?

options.label: A
options.text: Cognitive fluency is the ability to process information quickly, and listicles make it easier to do so.

options.label: B
options.text: Cognitive fluency is the ability to remember information, and listicles make it harder to do so.

options.label: C
options.text: Cognitive fluency is the ability to think critically, and listicles have no impact on it.

options.label: D
options.text: Cognitive fluency is the ability to focus, and listicles distract from it.

multiple-choice.question: According to a study, what happens when people are shown statements that are easy or difficult to read?

options.label: A
options.text: They are more likely to remember the difficult-to-read statements.

options.label: B
options.text: They are more likely to believe the easy-to-read statements.

options.label: C
options.text: They are more likely to ignore the difficult-to-read statements.

options.label: D
options.text: They are more likely to question the easy-to-read statements.

multiple-choice.question: What is the limitation of working memory, according to psychology professor Peter Dolittle?

options.label: A
options.text: It can hold a large amount of information for a long time.

options.label: B
options.text: It can hold a small amount of information for a short time.

options.label: C
options.text: It can hold a large amount of information for a short time.

options.label: D
options.text: It can hold a small amount of information for a long time.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's opinion about the effectiveness of listicles as a learning tool?

options.label: A
options.text: They are very effective for learning new information.

options.label: B
options.text: They are somewhat effective for learning new information.

options.label: C
options.text: They are not very effective for learning new information.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not at all effective for learning new information.

title: How many verb tenses are there in English? - Anna Ananichuk

options.text: To describe actions that are still happening at the time of reference

options.label: B
options.text: To describe actions that are finished

options.label: C
options.text: To describe a completed part of a continuous action

options.label: D
options.text: To describe an action that is not specified as continuous or discrete

options.label: C
options.text: French

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: D

title: Can you solve the dark coin riddle? - Lisa Winer

multiple-choice.question: You are in a dungeon with hundreds of coins, and you need to separate them into two piles so that each has the same number of coins facing silver side up. You counted exactly 20 silver-side-up coins in the pile initially. What can you do to achieve this?

options.label: A
options.text: Flip all the coins in the pile.

options.label: B
options.text: Move aside 20 coins and flip each one of them over.

options.label: C
options.text: Try to remember where the silver-facing coins were and separate them.

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Geometry

options.label: B
options.text: It will decrease by 20.

options.label: C
options.text: It will become equal to the number of silver-facing coins in the original pile.

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the properties of algebra.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the characteristics of probability.

options.text: A decrease in humidity

multiple-choice.question: What is a key characteristic of a swarm?

options.label: A
options.text: A single leader guides the group

options.label: B
options.text: Members of the swarm interact only with their nearest neighbors or through indirect cues

options.label: C
options.text: The swarm is always small in size

options.label: D
options.text: The swarm is always large in size

multiple-choice.question: What is a benefit of traveling in a swarm?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased energy expenditure

options.label: B
options.text: Reduced chance of finding a mate

options.label: C
options.text: Reduced chance of being captured by a predator

options.label: D
options.text: Increased wind resistance

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of swarm intelligence?

options.label: A
options.text: A single ant building a nest

options.label: B
options.text: An ant colony solving complex problems

options.label: C
options.text: A group of humans working individually

options.label: D
options.text: A computer program solving a simple problem

multiple-choice.question: How can swarm behavior be applied to technology?

options.label: A
options.text: By designing software for individual robots

options.label: B
options.text: By developing robots that can only navigate in open spaces

options.label: C
options.text: By creating teams of robots that can assist search and rescue missions

options.label: D
options.text: By developing drones that can only fly in straight lines

title: Why is Herodotus called “The Father of History”? - Mark Robinson

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the Ancient Greek writer who wrote "The Histories" in the 5th century BCE?

options.label: A
options.text: Herodotus of Athens

options.label: B
options.text: Herodotus of Halicarnassus

options.label: C
options.text: Leonidas of Sparta

options.label: D
options.text: Xerxes of Persia

multiple-choice.question: According to Herodotus, what event marked the beginning of the Persian Wars in 499 BCE?

options.label: A
options.text: The Battle of Marathon

options.label: B
options.text: The Athenians' assistance of a rebellion by Greeks living under Persian rule

options.label: C
options.text: The Persian King Darius's invasion of Greece

options.label: D
options.text: The heroic defeat of the Spartans at Thermopylae

options.label: A
options.text: Marathon

options.label: B
options.text: Thermopylae

options.label: C
options.text: Halicarnassus

options.label: D
options.text: Athens

options.label: B
options.text: Opsis

options.label: C
options.text: Akoe

options.label: D
options.text: Gnome

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: Can 100% renewable energy power the world? - Federico Rosei and Renzo Rosei

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated time frame for the world to run out of oil and gas at the current rate of consumption?

options.label: A
options.text: 20 years

options.label: B
options.text: 50 years

options.label: C
options.text: 100 years

options.label: D
options.text: 200 years

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the world's energy needs is currently provided by renewable energy sources?
What is the main challenge in using solar energy as a primary source of electricity?

options.label: A
options.text: The technology is not advanced enough to capture solar energy.

options.label: B
options.text: The sun does not radiate enough energy to meet our needs.

options.label: C
options.text: The efficiency of solar plants is limited, and energy transportation is a significant hurdle.

options.label: D
options.text: The cost of building solar plants is too high.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary challenge in using renewable energy to power transportation, such as cars and planes?

options.label: A
options.text: The cost of producing renewable energy is too high.

options.label: B
options.text: The technology is not advanced enough to capture renewable energy.

options.label: C
options.text: The energy density of batteries is not sufficient to power long-distance travel.

options.label: D
options.text: The infrastructure for transporting renewable energy is not developed.

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential solution to the challenge of energy storage and transportation in a renewable energy system?

options.label: A
options.text: Developing more efficient solar panels.

options.label: B
options.text: Building a global network of power lines to transport energy.

options.label: C
options.text: Discovering new superconducting materials that operate at room temperature.

options.label: D
options.text: Converting solar energy into chemical energy.

title: How long will human impacts last? - David Biello

multiple-choice.question: What is the Anthropocene, and what does it represent in the geologic time scale?

options.label: A
options.text: The Anthropocene is a new species of plants and animals that emerged due to human activities.

options.label: B
options.text: The Anthropocene is a new epoch in the geologic time scale that represents the profound impact of human activities on the planet.

options.label: C
options.text: The Anthropocene is a type of rock formation that is unique to the current geologic era.

options.label: D
options.text: The Anthropocene is a period of significant climate change that occurred in the distant past.

multiple-choice.question: What is the proposed start date for the Anthropocene, and what event is associated with this date?

options.label: A
options.text: The proposed start date is around 1950, and it is associated with the beginning of the Industrial Revolution.

options.label: B
options.text: The proposed start date is around 1950, and it is associated with the start of nuclear bomb testing around the world.

options.label: C
options.text: The proposed start date is around 1800, and it is associated with the beginning of the Industrial Revolution.

options.label: D
options.text: The proposed start date is around 2000, and it is associated with the widespread use of plastics.

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated amount of plastic produced by humans in the past 50 years, and what would be the effect of this plastic on the planet?

options.label: A
options.text: The estimated amount of plastic produced is around 1 billion metric tons, and it would cover a small portion of the Earth's surface.

options.label: B
options.text: The estimated amount of plastic produced is around 8 billion metric tons, and it would cover the whole world in a thin film.

options.label: C
options.text: The estimated amount of plastic produced is around 100 million metric tons, and it would have a negligible effect on the planet.

options.label: D
options.text: The estimated amount of plastic produced is around 500 million metric tons, and it would contribute to climate change.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of human activities on the diversity of plants and animals, and what are the implications of this effect?

options.label: A
options.text: Human activities have increased the diversity of plants and animals, making the ecosystem more resilient.

options.label: B
options.text: Human activities have had a negligible effect on the diversity of plants and animals.

options.label: C
options.text: Human activities have reduced the diversity of plants and animals, making the ecosystem less resilient.

options.label: D
options.text: Human activities have only affected the diversity of plants and animals in certain regions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the soot found in future rocks, and what does it correspond to?

options.label: A
options.text: The soot corresponds to a decrease in carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere.

options.label: B
options.text: The soot corresponds to an increase in oxygen levels in the atmosphere.

options.label: C
options.text: The soot corresponds to a meteoric rise in carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere.

options.label: D
options.text: The soot corresponds to a decrease in temperature levels.

title: History vs. Che Guevara - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What motivated Che Guevara to leave behind his life as a medical student and become a revolutionary?

options.label: A
options.text: He was inspired by the ideals of communism.

options.label: B
options.text: He was outraged by the poverty and misery he witnessed in rural Latin America.

options.label: C
options.text: He was seeking power and control.

options.label: D
options.text: He was motivated by a desire for revenge against the government.

options.label: A
options.text: The policies were successful in redistributing land to the poor.

options.label: B
options.text: The policies were met with resistance from the military and ultimately led to Árbenz's overthrow.

options.label: C
options.text: The policies had no significant impact on the country.

options.label: D
options.text: The policies led to a civil war.

options.label: B
options.text: He was a leader of the opposition to Fidel Castro.

options.label: C
options.text: He was a diplomat who helped negotiate a peaceful transition of power.

options.label: D
options.text: He was a bystander who had no involvement in the revolution.

multiple-choice.question: What was one of Che Guevara's achievements as a leader in Cuba?

options.label: A
options.text: He established a dictatorship and suppressed individual freedoms.

options.label: B
options.text: He oversaw the redistribution of land and helped establish universal education.

options.label: C
options.text: He led a successful economic reform program.

options.label: D
options.text: He improved relations with the United States.

multiple-choice.question: How did Che Guevara's life ultimately end?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: He died of natural causes in Cuba.

options.label: D
options.text: He was assassinated by a rival faction within the Cuban government.

title: What is the tragedy of the commons? - Nicholas Amendolare

multiple-choice.question: In the thought experiment about the fish pond, how many fish should each villager catch per day to maximize the food supply?
Who first described the phenomenon of the tragedy of the commons in a pamphlet in 1833?

options.label: A
options.text: Garrett Hardin

options.label: B
options.text: William Forster Lloyd

options.label: C
options.text: Adam Smith

options.label: D
options.text: Karl Marx

multiple-choice.question: What is the key feature of a tragedy of the commons?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides an opportunity for an individual to benefit themselves while spreading out any negative effects across the larger population.

options.label: B
options.text: It provides an opportunity for the community to come together and solve problems.

options.label: C
options.text: It provides an opportunity for individuals to work together for the common good.

options.label: D
options.text: It provides an opportunity for governments to regulate resources.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of the tragedy of the commons in real life?

options.label: A
options.text: The overuse of antibiotics leading to antibiotic-resistant bacteria

options.label: B
options.text: The use of renewable energy sources

options.label: C
options.text: The conservation of endangered species

options.label: D
options.text: The reduction of greenhouse gas emissions

multiple-choice.question: According to Garrett Hardin's lesson, what is the solution to the tragedy of the commons?

options.label: A
options.text: Individuals should prioritize their own self-interest

options.label: B
options.text: Governments should regulate resources

options.label: C
options.text: Communities should come together to solve problems

options.label: D
options.text: What's good for all of us is good for each of us

title: How often should you get a flu shot? - Melvin Sanicas

multiple-choice.question: Why do we need a new flu vaccine every year?

options.label: A
options.text: The flu virus has a long incubation period.

options.label: B
options.text: The flu virus has a high mutation rate and multiple subtypes.

options.label: C
options.text: The flu virus is highly contagious.

options.label: D
options.text: The flu virus only affects certain age groups.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the genetic material of the flu virus and other viruses?

options.label: A
options.text: The flu virus has DNA, while other viruses have RNA.

options.label: B
options.text: The flu virus has RNA, while other viruses have DNA.

options.label: C
options.text: The flu virus has a longer genetic code than other viruses.

options.label: D
options.text: The flu virus has a shorter genetic code than other viruses.

multiple-choice.question: How do vaccines work to prevent the flu?

options.label: A
options.text: Vaccines introduce a weakened live virus to the body.

options.label: B
options.text: Vaccines introduce inactivated viral antigens to stimulate an immune response.

options.label: C
options.text: Vaccines introduce antibodies to fight the flu virus.

options.label: D
options.text: Vaccines introduce a different strain of the flu virus.

multiple-choice.question: What is herd immunity, and how does it relate to flu vaccination?

options.label: A
options.text: Herd immunity is when a vaccinated person gets the flu anyway.

options.label: B
options.text: Herd immunity is when a community is protected from the flu because enough people are vaccinated.

options.label: C
options.text: Herd immunity is when a person is immune to the flu because they had it before.

options.label: D
options.text: Herd immunity is when a person is immune to the flu because they have a strong immune system.

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of developing a universal flu vaccine?

options.label: A
options.text: To protect against only the most common strains of the flu.

options.label: B
options.text: To protect against any strain of the flu, even mutated ones.

options.label: C
options.text: To eliminate the need for annual flu vaccination.

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the side effects of flu vaccination.

title: Why incompetent people think they're amazing - David Dunning

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the phenomenon where people overestimate their own abilities?

options.label: A
options.text: The Dunning-Kruger effect

options.label: B
options.text: The illusion of superiority

options.label: C
options.text: The confidence bias

options.label: D
options.text: The self-esteem boost

multiple-choice.question: According to research, what percentage of American drivers describe themselves as having above-average driving skills?
Who is most vulnerable to the Dunning-Kruger effect?

options.label: A
options.text: Only people with low intelligence

options.label: B
options.text: Only people with high intelligence

options.label: C
options.text: People with a moderate amount of experience or expertise

options.label: D
options.text: All of us, because we all have pockets of incompetence we don't recognize

multiple-choice.question: What is the double curse that people lacking knowledge and skill in particular areas suffer from, according to psychologists Dunning and Kruger?

options.label: A
options.text: They make mistakes and reach poor decisions, and they also lack the expertise needed to recognize how badly they're doing

options.label: B
options.text: They are too confident and blind to their weaknesses, and they also lack the motivation to improve

options.label: C
options.text: They are unaware of their strengths and weaknesses, and they also lack the ability to learn from feedback

options.label: D
options.text: They are too self-critical and lack the confidence to try new things, and they also lack the resilience to bounce back from failure

multiple-choice.question: What is one way to find out how good you actually are at various things, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Ask for feedback from other people and consider it, even if it's hard to hear

options.label: B
options.text: Trust your instincts and don't seek out advice from others

options.label: C
options.text: Compare yourself to others and try to one-up them

options.label: D
options.text: Focus on your strengths and ignore your weaknesses

title: Can you solve the egg drop riddle? - Yossi Elran

multiple-choice.question: A thief plans to steal a Fabergé egg from a 100-story building by dropping it out the window into a waiting truck. However, she suspects the egg at the top won't survive a 100-story drop. What is her plan to determine the highest floor from which an egg will survive the fall?

options.label: A
options.text: Test drop two souvenir eggs from every floor, starting from the top.

options.label: B
options.text: Test drop two souvenir eggs from different floors at larger intervals to narrow down the range.

options.label: C
options.text: Test drop one souvenir egg from every floor, starting from the bottom.

options.label: D
options.text: Test drop one souvenir egg from the top floor and hope it survives.

multiple-choice.question: If the thief only had one replica egg, what would be her only option to determine the highest floor from which an egg will survive the fall?

options.label: A
options.text: Start by dropping it from the top floor and go down one by one until it breaks.

options.label: B
options.text: Start by dropping it from the first floor and go up one by one until it breaks.

options.label: C
options.text: Drop it from every 10th floor until it breaks.

options.label: D
options.text: Drop it from a random floor and hope it survives.

multiple-choice.question: What is the maximum number of tries it would take to find the right floor if the thief starts by dropping the first egg from every 10th floor?

options.label: A
options.text: 10 tries

options.label: B
options.text: 19 tries

options.label: C
options.text: 50 tries

options.label: D
options.text: 100 tries

multiple-choice.question: What is the intuitive approach to dividing the building into sections to find the correct floor with the least number of tries?

options.label: A
options.text: Divide the building into equal sections.

options.label: B
options.text: Divide the building into sections where each interval is one floor smaller than the last.

options.label: C
options.text: Divide the building into sections where each interval is one floor larger than the last.

options.label: D
options.text: Divide the building into random sections.

multiple-choice.question: What is the minimum number of tries it would take to guarantee that the thief finds the right floor using the optimal approach?

options.label: A
options.text: 10 tries

options.label: B
options.text: 14 tries

options.label: C
options.text: 19 tries

options.label: D
options.text: 50 tries
